by Bradley Cohen
As students at an "elite"
university, are we part of a growing crisis in America? The MSE
symposium, entitled "Education
on the Edge: The Crisis of the
American University," will
assess the status of the university in America as it comes under
close scrutiny.
Distinguished educators and
scholars will visit our campus in
the next few weeks and discuss
the status of the current educational system, particularly in light
of several recent publications indicting higher learning on charges
of neglect, misguidance, and
misplaced goals. Co-chairs Andrea Kaufman and Jeff Blitz feel
this year's symposium has a
distinct focus for undergraduates,
as they cannot help but be affected by the expressed views of
education.
Kaufman described this year's
symposium as "an array of
perspectives on higher education,
student culture, curriculum, and
the role of the federal government
in higher education." Blitz added that higher education has
recently become a very controversial subject, citing as examples Stanford's recent debates

on the changes in its Western
Civilization requirement and
Allan Bloom's book, The Closing ofthe American Mind, which
was on the New York Times
Bestseller List for over a year.
This year's first speaker, Lauro
Cavazos, United States Secretary
of Education, will speak on "The
Role of Higher Education in
Restructuring Elementary and
Secondary Education." Kaufman
explained that Cavazos will
discuss how higher education sets
the tone for primary and secondary education throughout the
country.
As the Secretary of Education
for the "Education President,"
Cavazos has played a major role
in the recent Education Summit
and in the debate over the implementation of a national curriculum. He will speak
November 2 at 8:00 PM in,
Shriver Hall.
Michael Moffat, Professor of
Anthropology at Rutgers and
author of a book on
undergraduate life, Coming of
Age in New Jersey, will speak on
November 9 in the MSE
Library's Garrett Room. Moffat's lecture is entitled "College
Life: Undergraduate Culture and
Higher Education in the 1980's."

In researching his book, Moffat
"posed" as a freshman for two
years at Rutgers, observing
undergraduate slang and studying
students as a separate culture
within both the university and
general society. His lecture will
focus upon his observations of the
peculiarites of undergraduate life
and their meanings. Following
the lecture, a student panel will
respond to Moffat's claims and
offer insights.

Student Activities
fee debate continues
by Stephanie Sneddon
The student activities fee, a
controversial proposal being
debated in the Student Council,
promises to be a "big issue in
future elections," said Howie
Fried, HOP director and executive member of the Student
Council. The proposed $25.00
student activities fee would be
mandatory for all students,
payable each semester.
Fried added that the terms of
the proposed fee, "were still very
preliminary. We're still trying to
work out knots and obstacles."
One "knot" that the Council has
run into is how the funds
generated by 'the activities fee
should be allocated. Fried is
pushing for social programming
at Hopkins. "College life here is
boring and needs improvement,"
remarked one senior. Sophomore
Marisa Delacruz stressed the
need to "create more of a college
atmosphere, especially for the
large numbers of students living
off campus." Sophomore Todd

Ratner recognized the need for
better activities, saying, "There
are events on campus that nobody
goes to. If they have good events
it will be good, people will go.
It depends on what kinds of things
they do."
Other students have come up
with specific suggestions. Ratner
opted for "more concerts and live
events." Junior Danielle Grieco
would like to see "good comedy
events, so even people who drink
will find it entertaining and want
to go." Sophomore Misop Han
gave his conditional support for
the fee "if they have a bowling
alley," and junior Heather Stark
felt that there should be "more
opportunities to meet people in a
relaxed social atmosphere."

Hopkins Magazine
Editor Sea resigns
amidst controversy
by Jack Lipkin
Following the resignation of
Editor Alan Sea on October 13,
former Johns Hopkins Magazine
Editor Elise Hancock temporarily
resumed her position after a twoyear absence.
Ron Sauder, director of news
and information, gave this statement: "Alan has left as editor of
the magazine effective October
13, [and] Elise Hancock, the
former editor of the magazine for
many years, is now serving as interim editor."
Sauder declined to offer
specific reasons for Sea's departure, as did Vice President and
Secretary of the University Ross
Jones, currently head of communications and public affairs,
who viewed Sea's leaving as "an
isolated event." He did say that
there existed "philosophical differences between Alan and me
about the nature of the magazine
and how it was run."
Sea, who served as editor for
two years, declined to speak
about his situation on the record.
A University source told the
News-Letter that Sea had to resign
because he covered topics in a
way that was undesirable in the
eyes of University officials. For
example, the nine-page story on
the Five-Year Plan in the
February '89 issue presented
coverage of this controversial
plan and its possible impact on the
University in more detail than did
the Washington Post or the
Baltimore Sun. The source also
believed that the article was too
candid about the problems facing
the School of Arts and Sciences.
The source did not believe any
specific magazine story was the
reason for Sea's departure.
Hancock said she thought Sea
was "operating like a person on
a city magazine." She added,
"He was extremely competent,
but he had a perspective that was
not academic-oriented." Hancock said that the magazine lacked coverage of classes, students,
and "the things that will be there
long after the disputes [over

policies]." Her view was that the
magazine narrowed its focus to
policies which neither alumni nor
University officials found acceptable. Hancock saw this narrowed focus as an acute problem
since "the magazine is the
University's external voice."
Associate Editor Julia Ridgely
added that the magazine needed
to cover a broader range of campus events and life at Hopkins in
general because only about half
of the magazine's readers live in
the Baltimore area. The remainder are from out of state, and
about 5,000 readers live
overseas; therefore, Ridgely explained, the magazine should express "what it would be like to
go to Hopkins" and give "the
feel of the University."
With Hancock back as editor,
Jones felt that there would be no
radical change in the magazine's
operation. The December issue is
"on schedule." Ridgely added,
"It's not like administration decisions which can be put on hold;
in a publication, the show must
go on." Hancock concurred and
explained, "Alan left everything
in very good shape." She added,
"I'm just carrying on where Alan
left off."
According to Ridgely, "We're
not in that much more turmoil
than we usually are [right around
press time]; I think the [story on
the Californian] earthquake caused more problems."
Senior Science Writer Melissa
Hendricks said that "it's kind of
difficult being in the middle of a
feature story [under the guidance
of one editor] and having to shift
gears and switch the focus [of the
story] a little bit [under the
guidance of another editor.'"
However, according to Ridgely,
"Any two editors are going to
have different approaches to
covering stories."
The University source explained that there has always been a
policy emphasizing editorial
freedom at the magazine. Jones

2/OCTOBER 27, 1989

by Dawn Stephens
A montage of sparkle shirts,
blue skies, water-balloon
throwers and the occasional
camera-toting parent, Gilman
Quad burst into activity with the
ninth annual Phi Psi 500. While
"Gumby Does Twister" or "The
Strawberry Electric Soap Suds"
may sound like video games or
new NBC cartoon series, these
were only two among the twentyone teams who spent their Saturday demonstrating their prowess
in competitions including the infamous mattress race, bat race
and trunk-to-tail relay.
While they may have been
"Driven by Probability" some
teams were "Really Rotten," occasionally got "Lost at Sea with
Many Men" and were tested by
"Philosophic Cheese Whiz"; in
the end, these "Reflective
Hillbillies" raised a total of
$2700 for Santa Claus
Anonymous, exceeding Phi Psi's

goal for the event.
Considering that Santa Claus
Anonymous estimates that it takes
nine dollars to find a disadvantaged child's gift, the extraordinarily
successful event yielded enough
money to help 300 children
through the holidays this year.
Through the extensive work of
co-chairmen Marc Lebeau and
Kevin Ledger, the Phi Psi 500 not
only "went well" for the charity, as Lebeau commented, but
was a coming together, for sport
and silliness, of Greeks (eight
teams were fielded by fraternities,
male and female) along with
Greek alumni, other campuses
like UMBC, and fun-loving
independents.
Younger siblings, imported for
Parents' weekend, threaded
through the crowd as music
blasted, and the unfortunate relay
runners in the bat race caroused
off into all possible directions
after their ten spins around the
bat. Free hot chocolate was
slurped, tapes awarded to the first

group to "bitch about the
music," and while Phi Psi 500
trainee John McGready noted that
the planning was "a little
stressful," the stress was released quickly as a trashcan full of
leftover water balloons exploded
in an all-out water war. The
president of Santa Claus
Anonymous was one of the victims of such happy terrorism, but
he noted afterwards that he'd had
a great time.
It was a day of sun and fun
where the Hopkins Blue Jay
wandered, embarassing photos
were taken, camaraderie reigned
and the coveted Phi Psi 500 Tshirts were sold en masse. Most
of all, reminded Marc Lebeau,
the Phi Psi 500 was "not a
response to all .the current controversial fraternity discussions."
As Phi Psi looks towards a tenth
successful event next year, according to Lebeau, the Phi Psi 500
is simply one part of what fraternity life has always been about
here at Hopkins.

Council discussed the possibility
of using the University's East
Baltimore campus and/or Loyola
as possible exam sites.
The Athletics Committee announced a contest to create a new
fight song for Hopkins, with a
$50 prize going to the winner.
Entries can be to original music
or a familiar tune, and will be
judged by the Council. The winning fight song will premiere at
the first basketball game of the
season, at home against Catholic,
on November 21.
Junior class representative
Michele Wolf's proposal for a used book swap at the beginning of
the second semester was accepted
by the Council. This would allow
students to trade books without
going through the process of
reselling them to the bookstore.
The sophomore class is planning a canned-goods food drive for
November 12-19. Details on collection centers will be
forthcoming.
Of concern to the council was
the safety of the second southbound lane of Charles Street.
Citing the three accidents there in
the last few weeks, all in the socalled "suicide lane," Giangiulio
mentioned possible solutions
which he plans to outline in a letter to the campus' liaison to the
city of Baltimore's planning
board.
Ideas included moving the median outward so that both southbound lanes would be together,
separate from the northbound
lanes, placing mechanical gates to
be raised during the hours from
8-10 AM, when the lane is open,
and lowered at all other times,
and constructing a narrow median
to set off the "suicide lane" from
the regular, northbound ones. An
additional possibility would be to
place "rumble strips" in the
lane—strips that would make
noise when driven over and
would alert people to traffic.
Among other topics discussed
at Council was the possibility of
either purchasing a voting
machine for student elections or
hiring someone to create a computer program to make tabulating
the results easier. Also discussed were proposals for the gym's
locker facilities, and a shuttle to
the airport for Thanksgiving,
sign- up sheets will be available
before the holiday when people
have finalized their travel plans.

Activities fee debated
ACTIVITIES, from 1
include Student Council offices,
a lounge area, a room available
to students for various group
functions, and the radio station.
Reutter feels strongly that these
additions would "greatly improve
student life."
The Student Union concept has
been somewhat controversial.
Some feel that a Student Union
would be a great improvement in
student life. Freshman Michelle
Wildstein said, "It's a good idea
for nicer facilities for student offices and union/lounge areas. For
freshmen it would give more
alternatives to sitting in the
dorm." Sophomore Kathleen
Slattery said a Union "sounds
pretty good" and added, "I really
would like to see the Student
Union have a room that can be
rented out by students for different activities because that is
really hard to get now."
Delacruz also supported a Student Union. "It would be a good
place to see people, especially for
people who live off campus.
Maybe if it had a good arcade and
food." Juniors Mandy Darone,
Astrid Nielsen and Laura Elliott
like the idea of a social place for
students to go, but were skeptical
about the proposed location.
"The point of a Student Union,"
Darone said, "is a place to go
between classes and I am disappointed about the plans for an offcampus Student Union." Elliott
added, "I thought it a good idea
at first, but the plans seem to just
be for more offices and another

pinball machine. If the Union
were to be a good one I think it
would definitely improve student
life, but from what I've heard I
don't think it's a good idea."
Other students were concerned about when the Union would
be ready, feeling that it wouldn't
be fair to charge current students
if they weren't going to benefit
from the facility. Freshman
Jonathan Cohen strongly agreed,
estimating that "it probably won't
benefit anybody for 10 years."
Delacruz suggested, "If the Student Union takes a long time it
should be a staggered fee where
people who will be able to enjoy
it will pay more."
Student-run radio received
general approval. Freshman
Ethan Imboden, a disc jockey
from Berkeley, California, said
that he is "all for the radio station idea. I think it's a very good
idea to have the student radio station." Professor Bernard Shiffman of the Mathematics Department: "I think the students were
very disappointed when the
University took [the old station]
over."
Many students resented proposals for a student activities fee
as another aspect of the rising
costs of the University. "I think
it's ridiculous," an irate Cohen
said. "Tuition has been increased already. I pay about $40.00 a
class for inadequate facilities and
I feel very strongly that we
shouldn't have to pay any more
money. Students are becoming
merely an amount of money. It's
the principle of adding and ad-

ding." Junior Suzanne Muller
also questioned this need for
funds,"Why do they need money
from us all of a sudden? We pay
enough for tuition. It should go
towards something."
Administrators like Senior
Academic Adviser James
Goodyear sympathized with the
students, "I don't know why they
should charge $50.00 a year for
their own program because frankly it should be covered by tuition.
It seems inconsistent to raise tuition and not to provide more services." Dr. Philip Curtin of the
History Department commented,
"I know the University feels it's
poor, but they seem to have raised the fee enough lately and
should find other sources."
However, Shiffman feels the fee
would be nothing unusual, "It's
a fee that many other universities
have and I'm surprised that they
don't already have one."
Many students, like Wildstein,
feel that "$25.00 a semester isn't
that much compared to all the
money we're spending here
anyway." Steve Blank agreed,
saying, "Sure, my parents can
handle $25.00, what's a couple
dollars more?"
Shiffman further commented
that "there obviously needs to be
more money one way or the
other, whether it's an increased
tuition or an activities fee—as a
parent it means the same to me."
Many students feel that perhaps
a compromise should be reached
by lowering the fee to $10.00 per
semester instead of $25.00.

The punchline is this: I'm not
going to tell you what the punchline is.
I once heard a joke about a man
who was sitting on a bus across
from two total strangers. The two
strangers stared at him, making
the man extremely uncomfortable., until finally one of the two
strangers leaned over to the other
and whispered something to him,
pointing at the man. The two
strangers laughed, and the second
stranger then
whispered
something to the first. The
strangers laughed again.
Needless to say, the man was

When U.S. Secretary of Education Lauro Cavazos speaks
next Thursday at Shriver Hall, he will lead one of the most
impressive batteries of speakers ever to gather for the MSE
Symposium. This current series is striking not merely for
quality speakers—some of America's leading thinkers—
but for the unique combination of perspectives they represent. It's a combination particularly well-suited to address
the future of higher education in the United States. But
these speakers, to be sure, were not lured to Hopkins by
the elegance of its campus. Their presence is the product
of a full year's work by the Symposium co-chairs, Jeffrey Blitz and Andrea Kaufman.
Blitz and Kaufman began preparing this year's program
immediately upon their selection last fall. The two had to
articulate a unifying Symposium theme—this without any
commitments from potential speakers—and then construct
the series of lectures from there. It was hardly an enviable
task
The Symposium co-chairs not only gave up their summers and intersessions, but gave, too, fifteen hours of their
time every week throughout the academic year. Blitz and
Kaufman acted as the Symposium's full-time administrative
and secretarial staff. They established an Advisory Board
of Professors and Administrators, sent hundreds of letters,
made an equal number of phone calls and, as Kaufman
observed, had "to account for everything that may happen, and everything that's not going to happen."
Frustrating cases in point were the death of a contracted
Symposium speaker—A. Bartlett Giamatti—and the failure
of a major grant proposal, despite a month of preparation.
Simultaneously, all of this had to be coordinated with
the School of Arts and Sciences and the University's
Development Office, so that none of the Symposium's fundraising would conflict with previous capital campaigns.
The co-chairs were also faced with responsibility for arranging itineraries and accomodations for the speakers,
as well as coordinating dinners, choosing appropriate dinner guests, sending dinner invitations, picking up the
speakers from their various airports and train stations,
coordinating tours, arranging for electricians and
carpenters to prepare Shriver Hall, reserving rooms at the
overbooked Homewood campus—all the while aware that
they were representing the Johns Hopkins University and
everything that that entails.
Ultimately, Blitz and Kaufman were highly visible
representatives of Johns Hopkins undergraduate education.

Insulting fees
The proposal by some members of Student Council to
levy an activities fee on Hopkins students is an insult. As
tuition rises past the $14,000 mark, are we now expected
to pay additional money for programs that should be included in the whopping sum we already shell out each fall
and spring?
Some may think, reasonably, that the additional fee is
inconsiderable in light of the thousands of dollars spent
during an academic year. But it is the governing principle
behind the fee that matters. Hopkins' tuition has increased by an average of eight percent annually in recent years,
while class sizes have increased, course offerings have
shrunken and inadequate facilities have remained just that.
This ironic "pay more and get less" situation is not our
responsibility. Yet we are the ones who suffer for it, and
who are expected to solve it by surrendering increasingly
more money to the school.
The ostensible reason for proposing the fee is to increase
social programming—a laudable cause. Unfortunately,
many view the fee as a means to generate funds for a student union and other grandiose projects—projects which,
although needed, are the University's responsibity to
supply.
In examining proposed plans for a new union funded
by a fee, there are several problems. First, 2700 students
weighing in at $25 each would yield $135,000 a year, hardly enough for both programming and construction. Second,
building an adequate facility would take years, and the
money spent by current students will most likely not benefit
them directly, but rather, students of a distant, more
crowded Johns Hopkins University.
We don't deny the need for more social programming,
nor the desire for a firm Hopkins community. We do deny
the possible imposition of yet more fees, no matter how
small, which exist solely to relieve the University of its
responsibility to its students.

Sometimes you meet the most
interesting people in the most
remote places. Take this summer
in north central New Mexico, for
example. I was camped up in the
Sangre de Cristo mountains near
the Colorado border for three
weeks. Nearby is a construction
project to rebuild a 70-year-old
earthen dam that has begun to
leak excessively. As is the case
in any such construction project,
there is a need for numerous
heavy equipment operators and
other blue-collar types. The labor
pool of the nearby towns of
Costilla and Questa are not large
enough to fill the demand, so
workers from surrounding areas
(as far as California) migrate into the Costilla Valley for these
fairly well-paying jobs. Most rent
some form of housing near the
town of Costilla, but the individual of interest, the topic of
today's column, lives in his 1982
Dodge van. It's actually quite efficient; he has a nice bed in the
back so he can pull off the road
anywhere and get a good sleep.
He only need drive the 20 miles
into Costilla every two or three
days when supplies need
replenishing, rather than every
day like the rest of the workers.
My camp spot was attractive and
close to the dam, so he often
parked his van there to sleep.
Since we were both alone out
there we naturally engaged in
some conversations.
This guy never did tell me his
name; I'll just refer to him as
Holmes. Holmes is in his late
20's. I guess one could call him
a drifter. He travels around the
West from construction job to
construction job. Once he builds
up some cash, he quits his job and
travels around doing what he enjoys, mostly hunting. He then
finds a new job when his cash
runs out. It's really not a bad
lifestyle when you think about it.
Perhaps Holmes' lust for hunting
explains his belief that "Guns are
what made America America."
You would not have found this

guy voting for Maryland measure
-3 last November. But you probably wouldn't have found
Holmes in Maryland anyway; he
doesn't think much of this part of
the country. He was a little
curious about my collection of
rock samples from the Costilla
Valley.
"What is all this stuff? You.
looking for gold or something?"
(Standard question... most people think geologists do nothing
but look for gold.)
"No, these rocks are for my
research. I'm a geology student."
"Up in Oregon?"(He saw the
plates on my car.)
"No, in Maryland."
"The East Coast, huh? Whaddya think of that place?"
"Oh, it's OK for going to
school, but I wouldn't want to
live there forever."
"Yeah, I've been there before.
That place is just a big
clusterf---."
"Yeah, I know what you
mean. Lots of people around
there."
Holmes asks, "Have you ever
done any fishing up here?"
"No, I've never been into
fishing too much. Plus, I want to
get my geology work done and
get out of here."
"A couple weeks ago me and
another guy went hand fishing.
Ever gone hand fishing?"
"No. You mean you can just
grab the fish out of the water?"
"Sure. They hide under the
stream banks. Just reach under
and you're sure to find a fish. We
took out about 50 that one day."
At this time I recalled the
numerous signs posted along
Costilla Creek: Special trout
water. Please help keep this area

by Rachel Carpenter
This is what we ate, my two
companions and I, at Mencken's
Cultured Pearl, on the 23rd of
September 1989—vegetable
nachos(medium-spiced, $6.50),
vegetarian chili ($3.00), a
soweburrito ($5.50), a bean
enchilada-chicken burrito combination ($7.50), sour cream on
the side, three sodas, lots of
water, three coffees, and one
sopaipilla ($2.50). Total bill:
$32.00, $36.00 with tip. This is
how long it took us to be seated:
two minutes.(The couple behind
us in line: 40 minutes.)
The place seemed less eccentric than we'd expected; it seemed like a place we could bring our
parents. But then, maybe our
parents are just tremendously
cool. The walls were pale rose,
and the artwork was pastel landscapes. The waitresses wore matching black tank tops to confuse
us, and tables came with brown
paper tablecloths, and a mugful
of crayons to draw with. Diner
Number One said when she saw
the crayons, "Oooh—I bet this
means a long wait for the food,"
and of course she was right, but
then she's from New York where
I hear all the restaurants have
crayons at their tables.
Things like long waits for food
can be forgiven when you are
grateful to get a table at all, let
alone in two minutes. There was
lots to watch: the artwork mentioned above improved with gazing, the scrawlings taking shape
under our various sets of fingers,
the waiters and waitresses walking by, the people next to us and
their food, which certainly looked good.
Diner Number Two, an
engineer, had drawn a series of
sine curves and round pigs by the
time the nachos and the chili arrived. The nachos seemed more
like an open tortilla with beans,
cheese and vegetables (and sour
cream on the side) than the usual
chips. They were good,they were
more than good, they were the
best thing of the evening as it
turned out. If! went there again

I might get them as my dinner.
The vegetarian chili, we
agreed, needed more salt, and we
added some to improve it, but not
nearly to the level of the nachos.
Given Diner Number One's
history of MSG consumption it's
understandable, this reaching for
the salt shaker, stirring some in
and tasting it with a quizzical look
on her face, then adding more and
tasting it again, and saying to
Diner Number Two, "It makes
a difference—see, taste it."
Diner Number Two tasted it,

Barnstormers' Clever
'California Suite' Pleases
from Start to Finish
by Deborah Kanner
In 1776 Horace Walpole declared that the world
"is a comedy to those who think, a tragedy to
those who feel," and over 200 years later, the
Hopkins Barnstormers proved him right in their
production of Neil Simon's "California Suite."
Being a light comedy, the play did not take the
audience to any great emotional depths, but it did
succeed in drawing laughter via Simon's colorful, sly one-liners and the Barnstormers' usually
able handling of the material.
"California Suite" presents us with four very
different scenes, all set in the same deluxe Beverly
Hills hotel suite, and each composed of different
groups of characters. The first of these, "Visitor
from New York," introduces William Warren
(Lyle Roberts), a 45-year-old divorcee who drinks
tea instead of liquor, has given up on cigarettes
and Snickers bars, runs five miles and swims
twenty laps a day, and eats organically-grown
food.
A native New Yorker, William goes to the suite
to visit his first ex-wife, Hannah (Sarah Morton),
who has trekked to California to persuade their
only daughter to return with her to New York.
42 years old, still living in New York, Hannah
eats chili burgers—on wheat bread, she informs

him with a sneer—and visits her analyst regularly. She buries her emotions under a dense layer
of caustic, sarcastic remark—what Billy (as she
dubs him) calls her "train of venom." Despite
the facade, Hannah eventually reveals her warmer
side: that of a caring mother scared at the notion
of losing her daughter.
Morton and Roberts were both successful in
providing the audience with a keen sense of the
shifting emotions between them.'Although there
were some uneasy black spaces in dialogue, both
actors had some poignant moments. Roberts spoke
well and came across convincingly, and Morton
at times offered piercing glimpses of the pain
behind Hannah's rough exterior. Near the end of
the scene, she admits to Billy, "I'm not always
fond of me, either," and the line resonates strongly with all that we've seen.
"She was attractive," says Marvin Michaels in
scene two of the play. "She was a little tight and
she was paid for." This is Michaels' explanation
to his wife, Millie (Elin Hilderbrand), for the unconscious prostitute (Aliza Lirtzman) lying dormant in the suite's double bed. The Michaels, who
have come from Philadelphia for their nephew's
bar mitzvah, are a couple who plan for the worst
in life: they take separate flights out to California so as not to risk making their children orphans.

Big Issues behind
Manhattan Project
by Mark Friedman
Roland Joffe's "Fat Man and
Little Boy" is a heavyhanded account of the notorious World War
II Manhattan Project. It's a
remarkable piece of world
history, full of intrigue and conflict, although the presentation
here is a major disappointment.
The script is so laborious and
evasive that "Fat Man and Little
Boy" generates neither light nor
heat.
"Fat Man" and "Little Boy"
are the nicknames for the atomic
devices themselves, subsequently dropped over Nagasaki and
Hiroshima. Less than one year
after the Japanese bombing of
Pearl Habor, dozens of young
scientists were brought to New
Mexico by the United States
Government. Quarantined in justfounded Los Alamos, the goal of
the Manhattan Project was to
develop nuclear technology as
quickly and secretly as possible.
The physicists and civilians in
Los Alamos were only able to see
family members periodically, and
were forbidden to divulge details
of their work. The sacrifices that

the Manhattan Project involved are a good example of the
extraordinary lengths to which a
country will extend itself during
wartime. Unfortunately, few of
these special circumstances are
conveyed in the film.
The title of the film is also a
metaphor for political and scientific fathers of the bomb. General
Leslie R. Groves (Paul Newman,
wearing fifteen pounds of padding around his waist) is the
military ringmaster in New Mexico. He's got one watchful eye on
his deadlines, another on the progress of the international team of
scientists he's assembled.
Precocious physicist J. Robert
Oppenheimer(Dwight Schultz) is
the "Little Boy," questioning any
of Groves' administrative decisions that might cramp the
abilities of his underlings.
"Oppy," as he's called, buys
into the project quickly—perhaps
too quickly. This is representative
of the film's major flaw: it tells
us plenty that we don't need to
know in an effort to flesh out the
"spectacle" while omitting the
vital machinations of the main
characters.

GROSS ANATOMY
This aptly-titled film chronicles
the angst and joys of five first-year
medical students—it's something like
a "St. Elmo's Virus." They meet
over a corpse in the gross anatomy
course at the mythical Chandler
Medical School, have 3500 pages of
reading a week, yet still manage to
hit every cliched graduate school
dilemma: drugs, cheating, cutthroats, tough professors, and
overbearing fathers. These five are
no more than sketches, and are hardly cohesive; perhaps director Thom
Eberhardt didn't take chemistry.
(Unfortunately, the film glosses over
the most intriguing of the five: Kim
McCauley (Alice Carter), who has
a baby and is expecting another during spring semester.) Joe Slovak
(Matthew Modine) is conceited, irreverent, and annoying. He's supposed to be brilliant, but Modine
comes off like Dr. Joker,
transplanted from his role in "Full
Metal Jacket." He adores his analretentive lab partner Laurie Rorbach
(Daphne Zuniga), and is challenged
by Dr. Rachel Woodruff(Christine
Lahti), who is little more than a
"Paper Chase" clone. Instead of
studying, Joe pursues Laurie, who
jogs all the time and doesn't seem to
study much herself. In fact, it is
bookworm David Schreiner (Todd
Field), who takes speed and rises at
4:30 to study, who is "asked to
leave." One gets the feeling that
none of these people will ever be
qualified to be doctors: the students
who study the most flunk out. "St.
Elsewhere" keeps looking better and
better.
A DRY WHITE SEASON
Euzhan Palcy's South African
docu-drama may play loosely with
the facts, but the result is overpowering. History teacher Ben du Toit
(Donald Sutherland) lives the ideal
life of a white South African,
distanced from and largely ignorant
of his country's racial unrest. It takes
the horrible murder of his gardener's
son (during the 1976 Soweto uprising) to draw him into the atrocities
of Apartheid, much to the dismay of
his family and the South African
special police. Marlon Brando submits a top-flight performance as rotund barrister Sheldon McKenzie, an
over-the-hill civil rights champion
who takes one final case. Ben's life

unravels as he becomes inextricably
linked to the cause of freedom, and
he lives his final days much like the
South African blacks he has finally
made an effort to understand. "A
Dry White Season" has a heavy
moral message, but Palcy makes that
clear from the opening moments:
there's no deception or disappointment. Besides, the moral is the right
one, and tautly presented.
THE FABULOUS BAKER BOYS
Michelle Pfeiffer is Susie Diamond, the gum-chewing, sultrytoned wonder who breathes life into
Steve Kloves' directorial debut with
every breath she takes. Beau and Jeff
Bridges play Frank and Jack Baker,
lounge lizards on the ropes until
Susie stumbles into their life and
takes their stale piano act (and the
film) to another plane. Pfeiffer
stakes her claim as perhaps the most
beautiful and sexy film actress in
history. Diamond isn't a role she
sinks her teeth into—she sort of
wraps herself around it. The scenes
of the Boys and Susie together have
an undeniable chemistry and a
wonderful feel, which makes Susie's
exit all the more frustrating. She's
strangely absent from the final act,
and we're left with Frank, stuck in
suburbia with the kids; and Jack,
moping about his failures as a blues
pianist. Meanwhile, Susie, the
catalyst, has gone to sing vegetable
commercials. As "The Fabulous
Baker Boys" ends, you may wonder
why Kloves chose to break up such
a successful trio.

AN INNOCENT MAN
Peter Yates' prison drama is as
predictable and intelligence-insulting
as a bad TV movie. Tom Selleck
plays Jimmie Rainwood, a triumphant airline mechanic sent to prison
for a crime he didn't commit. While
in the big house, he watches a friend
burn to death and observes the gangrape of a white prisoner by a group
of black inmates, just for starters.
How could Selleck be anything but
innocent? He's predictably spineless
in prison, but when he gets paroled
after three years he's still a wimp,
even with the tutelage of prison
strongman Virgil Cane (F. Murray
Abraham). It would have been nice
for Selleck to turn into a sadistic
killer when he gets out of jail, but

Richard Cartwright

he looks as ready for a "Magnum
Pt." reunion as ever. Screenwriter
and ex-con Larry Brothers offers a
taste of gritty prison life, but the
drama doesn't hold when the
characters try to speak. The best
thing about "An Innocent Man"
is that the improvements made in the
California and Ohio prisons for the
film were left intact after shooting.
(Love the new electrified fence!)
Perhaps the filmmakers should have
been left there as well.
BLACK RAIN
Ridley Scott's vision of a gleaming Osaka is haunting, but it drops
like a lead weight in this overburdened Japan-bashing thriller and star
vehicle for Michael Douglas.
Douglas plays the crabby and slightly crooked New York Detective
Nick Conklin who, along with partner Charlie Vincent(Andy Garcia),
must escort Mafia wunderkind Sato
(Yusaku Matsuda) back to Japan
from New York City. But the
bumbling New Yorkers deliver Sato
right into the Mafia's hands, and
they are forced to stay in Osaka until they find him and clear Conklin's
name. Garcia shines as Vincent, and
his early exit leaves "Black Rain"
wanting. Kate Capshaw, irrelevant
as the wisecracking geisha girl Joyce
Kingsley, gets the film's hokiest

faculty on programs which might

IRIS.

Ice hockey skates past Salisbury,
in 6-2 opening victory
by Jay Calkins
Baltimore, October 22.
The Johns Hopkins ice hockey
team started its season in impressive fashion as they rolled
past Salisbury State by a
score of 6-2.
As anticipated, the defense was
stifling as they limited the
Seagulls to just 20 shots. Junior
goaltender Dave Bowyer was
outstanding in the net as he made
18 saves, but he was quick to
credit his defense for much of his
success. "Our guys really put the
clamp on their offense. It was a
challenge for me to keep my concentration while facing so few
shots."
The offense, thought to be the
question mark for the team, provided the needed punch with a
balanced scoring attack in which
five different Blue Jays scored.
The first period began as a
stalemate as both teams held
the other in check for the first 6
minutes. The Jays drew first
blood, however, as freshman
Jason Sprague sent a beautiful
pass across the middle to senior
Jack Calkins, who was waiting on
the left post to drive it home. One
minute later, Sprague completed
a spin move to open up the ice
and again found Calkins on the
post where Jack was able to collect his second goal of the night.
The Jays maintained this torrid

first period pace when playmaker
Sprague assisted for the third time
by hitting Pierre DeMatos high in
the slot. DeMatos took one step
toward the goal before rifling a
shot past the left shoulder of
Salisbury's goalie to give
Hopkins a 3-0 advantage.
After letting up a goal at the tail
end of the first period, the
stickmen took the ice in the second period looking to leave their
opponents in the dust. Right from
the opening whistle the Jays were
all over them, and the hustle paid
off. Jon Lowthert took a pass
from senior captain Mike
Holmes deep in his own zone.
Lowthert skated the puck by two
defenders before making a blind
behind the back pass to Norm
Shephard, who was wide open in
front of the net. Shephard easily
beat the Salisbury goalie to extend
the Jays' lead to 4-1.
After a 7-minute lull in the action, Phil Schied made a superb
defensive play when he successfully thwarted the efforts of
two rushing Salisbury forwards.
Seeing the five-on-three advantage he had created, Schied found
Kirk Perry all alone beyond the
Salisbury defense. Perry approached the goal on a difficult
angle from the right side, but was
still able to slip the puck between
the legs of the opposing
goaltender.
A minute and a half later

Holmes found Dave Boxenbaum
at center ice, where Boxenbaum
was able to beat two deferders in
order to set up a snap shot from
15 feet out. Salisbury's goalie appeared to make the save, but
juggled the puck into his own net
to make the score 6-1.
Salisbury responded to this last
goal 50 seconds later, but were
unable to create any momentum
for themselves.
The third period provided no
scoring, due largely to fine
goaltending. Bowyer frustrated
the Salisbury offense by making
repeated saves. "He's unbeatable
on that glove side," commented
Holmes.
The season-opening victory
was very satisfying for the team,
but they realize that the Salisbury
squad was not representative of
the type of competition they will
face this season. "It was a great
win," offered Coach Steve
Wirth, "but we're going to have
to improve even more in order to
be competitive in league play.
Against teams like Georgetown
we have to stay intense for the
whole game and not just for two
periods like today."
Next up for the hockey team is
rival Western Maryland on Saturday at 7:15 p.m. at Northwest Ice
Rink, on Falls Road and Kelly
Street in Mount Washington
Village.

Cambridge, MA, Oct. 22—
Two varsity crew teams
represented the Johns Hopkins
University at the 25th annual
Head of the Charles Regatta. In
its first Head race of the season,
a young, strong men's
heavyweight boat placed 15th out
of 38 in the Club Four event. A
more experienced women's crew
returning from a successful spring
season pulled in a 7th place performance out of 23 in the Championship Four category.
A Head race is typically 21
2 to
/
3½ miles long, a demanding
distance. Boats are started one at
a time at ten-second intervals.
The challenge of a Head race lies
in racing against the clock while
trying to pass boats ahead and
hold off boats from behind.
Headracing, especially on the
Charles River, is the greatest test
of a coxswain's abilities, particularly in terms of steering the
most efficient path and keeping
the rowers motivated.
At 9:00 AM, the men's Club
Fours began powering down the
course. Bow number 29 shot into view propelled by the drive of
strokeman Dan Taylor, Chris
Ros, Greg Stella, and bowman
Erik Plautz. Cox E.K. Kim, in
firm control, steered past the Latvian National Masters boat from
the U.S.S.R. Despite a hairraising clashing of blades with the

College of St. Thomas, Minnesota, the Hopkins Four and
Kim remained cool and finished
in 19:29.
At 2:55 p.m., the starting time
of the Championship Four event
bore down, winds wound up, tensions monted and anxieties
climaxed.
Coxswain Veronica Rodriguez
assumed strategic position as she
motivated her rowers through the
start. Over the three-mile stretch,
the Hopkins Four outstripped two
competitors while nipping at the
stern of the Seattle crew.
Assisted ty the steady power of
stroke Kim Roberts, Inge Schlate,
and Kelly Kieffer, Rodriguez
coxed a strategically brilliant boat
race. The seventh place finish at
21:36 is impressive, considering
such competition as the firstplace national powerhouse Boston
Rowing Center (20:06), secondplace Vancouver Rowing Club
Canada and such highly regarded college crews as U.C.L.A.,
H a rand
Wisconsin,
vard/Radcliffe. The women's
performance is the strongest ever
of a Hopkins crew entered in the
Head of the Charles Regatta.
The success on the Charles
River of both the men's and
women's crews bodes good
tidings for the three remaining
races of the fall season. The varsity men's Lightweight Eight and
the men's and women's Novice
Eights are expected to join them
in future victories.

A fall for lacrosse

Soccer captures pair

Loyola shocks Jays in overtime
by Josh Orenstein
When Brian Kroneberger lifted
Loyola College to an 11-10 victory over the Blue Jays in the first
round of the Choice Visa
Lacrosse Classic, disappointment
and frustration were inevitable.
But last weekend's game has to
be kept in perspective. It was an
off-season exhibition without any
effect on rankings or records.
"The worst thing anyone could
do now is push the panic button,"
said head coach Don Zimmerman. "If anyone should push it,
it's me, and I'm certainly not."
For the first 58 minutes of
regulation, the Blue Jays
displayed a typical, successful
performance: the Jays started off
very strong, held a slim lead at
halftime, dominated the third
quarter, and were in control in the
fourth. With a 10-6 Hopkins lead
and less than two minutes remaining, all looked well. So Zimmerman relaxed and substituted
extensively.
Brian Kroneberger cut the

Hopkins margin to three goals
with one minute, 52 seconds to
play. Still, all was well. Then
came the two-pointer. For the
Classic, Choice Visa introduced
a two-point goal, awarded on any
goal scored on a shot taken between the midfield line and a
semicircular arc extending 17
yards from the center of the
crease. The two-point goal will
not be used in games this spring.
Hopkins had benefitted first
from the innovation, as Greg Kelly beat Loyola goalie Charlie
Toomey from 17 feet with 22
seconds remaining in the third
period to increase a 7-3 Jay lead
to 9-3. At that point, the twopoint idea seemed novel, but
rather insignificant.
Kroneberger's two-pointer
with 67 seconds remaining
changed that thinking. Suddenly
the Greyhounds trailed by only
one goal. Zimmerman returned to
his starting troops, but it Was too
late. Momentum was lost, and the
'Hounds were hungry.
Loyola's Paul Cantabene won

the ensuing faceoff, raced down
the field, and fired past allAmerican goaltender Quint
Kessenich to tie the game. One
minute, 47 seconds into overtime
Kroneberger ended it.
"I've got to give Loyola a lot
of credit," said Zimmerman.
"They hung tough. Not to take
anything away from them, but I
take full responsibility for the
loss. I learned something about
the two-pointer today. I was
coaching without thinking about
it, and I'm at fault for that.—
Loyola coach Dave Cottle was
reserved in his enthusiasm about
defeating last year's national
runner-up. "It was a good
game," said the coach, "but all
it means is that we played tough
in a fall game."
Sunday, in the tournament's
consolation game, the Jays released their frustration on MarylandBaltimore County, earning a 20-6
conquest. It was an enjoyable
rout, but only a fall game.

Johns Hopkins' varsity rifle
started the year plagued by ill fortune, but the team still managed
to make strong showings in its
first three matches this year.
During the summer, an ROTC
instructor, much to the chagrin of
the rifle team and the Athletic
Department, requested a government environmental test of the
Hopkins rifle range. The test
found the range in violation of
lead dust safety levels, and the
state of Maryland condemned and
sealed the rifle range and fined
the Athletic Department $5000.
The loss of the range severely
reduced the amount of practice
before the season's first three
matches, and the lack of practice
showed itself in the inconsistent
scores of the teams' top shooters.
However, the team as a whole did
remarkably well in the first match
at King's College in Pennsylvania. Hopkins earned 1975
points out of a possible 2400.
This score beat Cornell by 25
points.
Last weekend, the rifle team
shot an early morning match at
Navy. The Jays lost to the Division I rifle giant, but did well
against DePaul University. Then,
the team travelled to Lexington,
Virginia, to fire against Virginia
Military Institute and Army in a
Sunday morning shootout. The
two Division I schools beat Johns
Hopkins as expected, but the
Hopkins shooters produced consistently high scores, including a
perfect 100 prone target shot by
senior Jim Kielkopf.
The matches are shot using .22
caliber precision target rifles at a
range of fifty feet. The targets,
or "bulls" are coin-sized black
circles, and the ten-point "bull's
eye— is the size of a pin head. A

by Jack Lipkin
Following the resignation of
Editor Alan Sea on October 13,
former Johns Hopkins Magazine
Editor Elise Hancock temporarily
resumed her position after a twoyear absence.
Ron Sauder, director of news
and information, gave this statement: "Alan has left as editor of
the magazine effective October
13, [and] Elise Hancock, the
former editor of the magazine for
many years, is now serving as interim editor."
Sauder declined to offer
specific reasons for Sea's departure, as did Vice President and
Secretary of the University Ross
Jones, currently head of communications and public affairs,
who viewed Sea's leaving as "an
isolated event." He did say that
there existed "philosophical differences between Alan and me
about the nature of the magazine
and how it was run."
Sea, who served as editor for
two years, declined to speak
about his situation on the record.
A University source told the
News-Letter that Sea had to resign

example, the nine-page story on

coverage of this controversial
plan and its possible impact on the
University in more detail than did
the Washington Post or the
Baltimore Sun. The source also
believed that the article was too
candid about the problems facing
the School of Arts and Sciences.
The source did not believe any
specific magazine story was the
reason for Sea's departure.
Hancock said she thought Sea
was "operating like a person on
a city magazine." She added,
"He was extremely competent,
but he had a perspective that was
not academic-oriented." Hancock said that the magazine lacked coverage of classes, students,
and "the things that will be there
long after the disputes [over

policies]." Her view was that the
magazine narrowed its focus to
policies which neither alumni nor
University officials found acceptable. Hancock saw this narrowed focus as an acute problem

University's external voice."

added that the magazine needed
to cover a broader range of campus events and life at Hopkins in

of the magazine's readers live in
the Baltimore area. The remainder are from out of state, and
about 5,000 readers live
overseas; therefore, Ridgely explained, the magazine should express "what it would be like to
go to Hopkins" and give "the
feel of the University."
With Hancock back as editor,
Jones felt that there would be no
radical change in the magazine's
operation. The December issue is
"on schedule." Ridgely added,
"It's not like administration decisions which can be put on hold;
in a publication, the show must
go on." Hancock concurred and
explained, "Alan left everything
in very good shape." She added,
"I'm just carrying on where Alan
left off."
According to Ridgely, "We're
not in that much more turmoil

by Dawn Stephens
A montage of sparkle shirts,
blue skies, water-balloon
throwers and the occasional
camera-toting parent, Gilman
Quad burst into activity with the
ninth annual Phi Psi 500. While
"Gumby Does Twister" or "The
Strawberry Electric Soap Suds"
may sound like video games or
new NBC cartoon series, these
were only two among the twentyone teams who spent their Saturday demonstrating their prowess
in competitions including the infamous mattress race, bat race
and trunk-to-tail relay.
While they may have been
"Driven by Probability" some
teams were "Really Rotten," occasionally got "Lost at Sea with
Many Men" and were tested by
"Philosophic Cheese Whiz"; in
the end, these "Reflective
Hillbillies" raised a total of
$2700 for Santa Claus
Anonymous, exceeding Phi Psi's

goal for the event.
Considering that Santa Claus
Anonymous estimates that it takes
nine dollars to find a disadvantaged child's gift, the extraordinarily
successful event yielded enough
money to help 300 children
through the holidays this year.
Through the extensive work of
co-chairmen Marc Lebeau and
Kevin Ledger, the Phi Psi 500 not
only "went well" for the charity, as Lebeau commented, but
was a coming together, for sport
and silliness, of Greeks (eight
teams were fielded by fraternities,
male and female) along with
Greek alumni, other campuses
like UMBC, and fun-loving
independents.
Younger siblings, imported for
Parents' weekend, threaded
through the crowd as music
blasted, and the unfortunate relay
runners in the bat race caroused
off into all possible directions
after their ten spins around the
bat. Free hot chocolate was
slurped, tapes awarded to the first

group to "bitch about the
music," and while Phi Psi 500
trainee John McGready noted that
the planning was "a little
stressful," the stress was released quickly as a trashcan full of
leftover water balloons exploded
in an all-out water war. The
president of Santa Claus
Anonymous was one of the victims of such happy terrorism, but
he noted afterwards that he'd had
a great time.
It was a day of sun and fun
where the Hopkins Blue Jay
wandered, embarassing photos
were taken, camaraderie reigned
and the coveted Phi Psi 500 Tshirts were sold en masse. Most
of all, reminded Marc Lebeau,
the Phi Psi 500 was "not a
response to all .the current controversial fraternity discussions."
As Phi Psi looks towards a tenth
successful event next year, according to Lebeau, the Phi Psi 500
is simply one part of what fraternity life has always been about
here at Hopkins.

impressive batteries of speakers ever to gather for the MSE
Symposium. This current series is striking not merely for
quality speakers—some of America's leading thinkers—
but for the unique combination of perspectives they represent. It's a combination particularly well-suited to address
the future of higher education in the United States. But
these speakers, to be sure, were not lured to Hopkins by
the elegance of its campus. Their presence is the product
of a full year's work by the Symposium co-chairs, Jeffrey Blitz and Andrea Kaufman.
Blitz and Kaufman began preparing this year's program
immediately upon their selection last fall. The two had to
articulate a unifying Symposium theme—this without any
commitments from potential speakers—and then construct
the series of lectures from there. It was hardly an enviable
task
The Symposium co-chairs not only gave up their summers and intersessions, but gave, too, fifteen hours of their
time every week throughout the academic year. Blitz and
Kaufman acted as the Symposium's full-time administrative
and secretarial staff. They established an Advisory Board
of Professors and Administrators, sent hundreds of letters,
made an equal number of phone calls and, as Kaufman
observed, had "to account for everything that may happen, and everything that's not going to happen."
Frustrating cases in point were the death of a contracted
Symposium speaker—A. Bartlett Giamatti—and the failure
of a major grant proposal, despite a month of preparation.
Simultaneously, all of this had to be coordinated with
the School of Arts and Sciences and the University's
Development Office, so that none of the Symposium's fundraising would conflict with previous capital campaigns.
The co-chairs were also faced with responsibility for arranging itineraries and accomodations for the speakers,
as well as coordinating dinners, choosing appropriate dinner guests, sending dinner invitations, picking up the
speakers from their various airports and train stations,
coordinating tours, arranging for electricians and
carpenters to prepare Shriver Hall, reserving rooms at the
overbooked Homewood campus—all the while aware that
they were representing the Johns Hopkins University and
everything that that entails.
Ultimately, Blitz and Kaufman were highly visible
representatives of Johns Hopkins undergraduate education.

Insulting fees
The proposal by some members of Student Council to
levy an activities fee on Hopkins students is an insult. As
tuition rises past the $14,000 mark, are we now expected
to pay additional money for programs that should be included in the whopping sum we already shell out each fall
and spring?
Some may think, reasonably, that the additional fee is
inconsiderable in light of the thousands of dollars spent
during an academic year. But it is the governing principle
behind the fee that matters. Hopkins' tuition has increased by an average of eight percent annually in recent years,
while class sizes have increased, course offerings have
shrunken and inadequate facilities have remained just that.
This ironic "pay more and get less" situation is not our
responsibility. Yet we are the ones who suffer for it, and
who are expected to solve it by surrendering increasingly
more money to the school.
The ostensible reason for proposing the fee is to increase
social programming—a laudable cause. Unfortunately,
many view the fee as a means to generate funds for a student union and other grandiose projects—projects which,
although needed, are the University's responsibity to
supply.
In examining proposed plans for a new union funded
by a fee, there are several problems. First, 2700 students
weighing in at $25 each would yield $135,000 a year, hardly enough for both programming and construction. Second,
building an adequate facility would take years, and the
money spent by current students will most likely not benefit
them directly, but rather, students of a distant, more
crowded Johns Hopkins University.
We don't deny the need for more social programming,
nor the desire for a firm Hopkins community. We do deny
the possible imposition of yet more fees, no matter how
small, which exist solely to relieve the University of its
responsibility to its students.

futures. To put Spring Fair on the
same date as MCATs would be
a colossal error in judgment and
a frightening statement of our
priorities.

the myriad scents and sounds that
are inevitably produced by Spring
Fair. To put Fair on the same date
as MCATs would needlessly
jeopardize the mental state of
those taking the exam.

seemingly limited salience to premeds that the decision made by

protect and promote the needs

keeping Fair on the same date as

come across every year,
something of a captive market.

your editor included, a situation

by Rachel Carpenter
This is what we ate, my two
companions and I, at Mencken's
Cultured Pearl, on the 23rd of
September 1989—vegetable
nachos(medium-spiced, $6.50),
vegetarian chili ($3.00), a
soweburrito ($5.50), a bean
enchilada-chicken burrito combination ($7.50), sour cream on
the side, three sodas, lots of
water, three coffees, and one
sopaipilla ($2.50). Total bill:
$32.00, $36.00 with tip. This is
how long it took us to be seated:
two minutes.(The couple behind
us in line: 40 minutes.)
The place seemed less eccentric than we'd expected; it seemed like a place we could bring our
parents. But then, maybe our
parents are just tremendously
cool. The walls were pale rose,
and the artwork was pastel landscapes. The waitresses wore matching black tank tops to confuse
us, and tables came with brown
paper tablecloths, and a mugful
of crayons to draw with. Diner
Number One said when she saw
the crayons, "Oooh—I bet this
means a long wait for the food,"
and of course she was right, but
then she's from New York where
I hear all the restaurants have
crayons at their tables.
Things like long waits for food
can be forgiven when you are
grateful to get a table at all, let
alone in two minutes. There was
lots to watch: the artwork mentioned above improved with gazing, the scrawlings taking shape
under our various sets of fingers,
the waiters and waitresses walking by, the people next to us and
their food, which certainly looked good.
Diner Number Two, an
engineer, had drawn a series of
sine curves and round pigs by the
time the nachos and the chili arrived. The nachos seemed more
like an open tortilla with beans,
cheese and vegetables (and sour
cream on the side) than the usual
chips. They were good,they were
more than good, they were the
best thing of the evening as it
turned out. If! went there again

I might get them as my dinner.
The vegetarian chili, we
agreed, needed more salt, and we
added some to improve it, but not
nearly to the level of the nachos.
Given Diner Number One's
history of MSG consumption it's
understandable, this reaching for
the salt shaker, stirring some in
and tasting it with a quizzical look
on her face, then adding more and
tasting it again, and saying to
Diner Number Two, "It makes
a difference—see, taste it."
Diner Number Two tasted it,
and he agreed, but then we all
agreed that it just wasn't that
good anyway, no matter how
much salt we threw in it, and so
when the waitress brought us the
main course the chili bowl had
four spoonfuls left in it at least.
When the dinners came we
decided that the best food of the
main course was mine, the
vegetarian chimichanga, a fried
tortilla with beans and cheese and
guacamole (not as much as I'd
have liked) and sour cream.
Diner Number One added salt
to her enchilada and bean combination to no avail, and then said
that her dinner was the worst of
all; she said, after lifting the plate
in a vain effort to pawn it off on
one of us, "Look ,this is just a
lump of beans and cheese." I
tasted the bean enchilada and she
was right, it tasted like beans and
a bit of cheese and some more
beans, with some salt on the top.
Our waitress asked us if we
wanted it wrapped to go and we
said no thanks, and she left with
the plates and came back with the
check and walked away. When
we caught her again we ordered
coffees and a sopaipilla. The coffee came in Irish coffee glasses
and the sopaipilla was a fried tortilla with honey and powdered
sugar on it. We liked it—it was
like very crisp funnel cake.
When we left the hostess ran
outside with my glasses that I'd

Barnstormers' Clever
'California Suite' Pleases
from Start to Finish
by Deborah Kanner
In 1776 Horace Walpole declared that the world
"is a comedy to those who think, a tragedy to
those who feel," and over 200 years later, the
Hopkins Barnstormers proved him right in their
production of Neil Simon's "California Suite."
Being a light comedy, the play did not take the
audience to any great emotional depths, but it did
succeed in drawing laughter via Simon's colorful, sly one-liners and the Barnstormers' usually
able handling of the material.
"California Suite" presents us with four very
different scenes, all set in the same deluxe Beverly
Hills hotel suite, and each composed of different
groups of characters. The first of these, "Visitor
from New York," introduces William Warren
(Lyle Roberts), a 45-year-old divorcee who drinks
tea instead of liquor, has given up on cigarettes
and Snickers bars, runs five miles and swims
twenty laps a day, and eats organically-grown
food.
A native New Yorker, William goes to the suite
to visit his first ex-wife, Hannah (Sarah Morton),
who has trekked to California to persuade their
only daughter to return with her to New York.
42 years old, still living in New York, Hannah
eats chili burgers—on wheat bread, she informs

him with a sneer—and visits her analyst regularly. She buries her emotions under a dense layer
of caustic, sarcastic remark—what Billy (as she
dubs him) calls her "train of venom." Despite
the facade, Hannah eventually reveals her warmer
side: that of a caring mother scared at the notion
of losing her daughter.
Morton and Roberts were both successful in
providing the audience with a keen sense of the
shifting emotions between them.'Although there
were some uneasy black spaces in dialogue, both
actors had some poignant moments. Roberts spoke
well and came across convincingly, and Morton
at times offered piercing glimpses of the pain
behind Hannah's rough exterior. Near the end of
the scene, she admits to Billy, "I'm not always
fond of me, either," and the line resonates strongly with all that we've seen.
"She was attractive," says Marvin Michaels in
scene two of the play. "She was a little tight and
she was paid for." This is Michaels' explanation
to his wife, Millie (Elin Hilderbrand), for the unconscious prostitute (Aliza Lirtzman) lying dormant in the suite's double bed. The Michaels, who
have come from Philadelphia for their nephew's
bar mitzvah, are a couple who plan for the worst
in life: they take separate flights out to California so as not to risk making their children orphans.

Big Issues behind
Manhattan Project
by Mark Friedman
Roland Joffe's "Fat Man and
Little Boy" is a heavyhanded account of the notorious World War
II Manhattan Project. It's a
remarkable piece of world
history, full of intrigue and conflict, although the presentation
here is a major disappointment.
The script is so laborious and
evasive that "Fat Man and Little
Boy" generates neither light nor
heat.
"Fat Man" and "Little Boy"
are the nicknames for the atomic
devices themselves, subsequently dropped over Nagasaki and
Hiroshima. Less than one year
after the Japanese bombing of
Pearl Habor, dozens of young
scientists were brought to New
Mexico by the United States
Government. Quarantined in justfounded Los Alamos, the goal of
the Manhattan Project was to
develop nuclear technology as
quickly and secretly as possible.
The physicists and civilians in
Los Alamos were only able to see
family members periodically, and
were forbidden to divulge details
of their work. The sacrifices that

the Manhattan Project involved are a good example of the
extraordinary lengths to which a
country will extend itself during
wartime. Unfortunately, few of
these special circumstances are
conveyed in the film.
The title of the film is also a
metaphor for political and scientific fathers of the bomb. General
Leslie R. Groves (Paul Newman,
wearing fifteen pounds of padding around his waist) is the
military ringmaster in New Mexico. He's got one watchful eye on
his deadlines, another on the progress of the international team of
scientists he's assembled.
Precocious physicist J. Robert
Oppenheimer(Dwight Schultz) is
the "Little Boy," questioning any
of Groves' administrative decisions that might cramp the
abilities of his underlings.
"Oppy," as he's called, buys
into the project quickly—perhaps
too quickly. This is representative
of the film's major flaw: it tells
us plenty that we don't need to
know in an effort to flesh out the
"spectacle" while omitting the
vital machinations of the main
characters.

This aptly-titled film chronicles
the angst and joys of five first-year
medical students—it's something like
a "St. Elmo's Virus." They meet
over a corpse in the gross anatomy
course at the mythical Chandler
Medical School, have 3500 pages of
reading a week, yet still manage to
hit every cliched graduate school
dilemma: drugs, cheating, cutthroats, tough professors, and
overbearing fathers. These five are
no more than sketches, and are hardly cohesive; perhaps director Thom
Eberhardt didn't take chemistry.
(Unfortunately, the film glosses over
the most intriguing of the five: Kim
McCauley (Alice Carter), who has
a baby and is expecting another during spring semester.) Joe Slovak
(Matthew Modine) is conceited, irreverent, and annoying. He's supposed to be brilliant, but Modine
comes off like Dr. Joker,
transplanted from his role in "Full
Metal Jacket." He adores his analretentive lab partner Laurie Rorbach
(Daphne Zuniga), and is challenged
by Dr. Rachel Woodruff(Christine
Lahti), who is little more than a
"Paper Chase" clone. Instead of
studying, Joe pursues Laurie, who
jogs all the time and doesn't seem to
study much herself. In fact, it is
bookworm David Schreiner (Todd
Field), who takes speed and rises at
4:30 to study, who is "asked to
leave." One gets the feeling that
none of these people will ever be
qualified to be doctors: the students
who study the most flunk out. "St.
Elsewhere" keeps looking better and
better.
A DRY WHITE SEASON
Euzhan Palcy's South African
docu-drama may play loosely with
the facts, but the result is overpowering. History teacher Ben du Toit
(Donald Sutherland) lives the ideal
life of a white South African,
distanced from and largely ignorant
of his country's racial unrest. It takes
the horrible murder of his gardener's
son (during the 1976 Soweto uprising) to draw him into the atrocities
of Apartheid, much to the dismay of
his family and the South African
special police. Marlon Brando submits a top-flight performance as rotund barrister Sheldon McKenzie, an
over-the-hill civil rights champion
who takes one final case. Ben's life

unravels as he becomes inextricably
linked to the cause of freedom, and
he lives his final days much like the
South African blacks he has finally
made an effort to understand. "A
Dry White Season" has a heavy
moral message, but Palcy makes that
clear from the opening moments:
there's no deception or disappointment. Besides, the moral is the right
one, and tautly presented.
THE FABULOUS BAKER BOYS
Michelle Pfeiffer is Susie Diamond, the gum-chewing, sultrytoned wonder who breathes life into
Steve Kloves' directorial debut with
every breath she takes. Beau and Jeff
Bridges play Frank and Jack Baker,
lounge lizards on the ropes until
Susie stumbles into their life and
takes their stale piano act (and the
film) to another plane. Pfeiffer
stakes her claim as perhaps the most
beautiful and sexy film actress in
history. Diamond isn't a role she
sinks her teeth into—she sort of
wraps herself around it. The scenes
of the Boys and Susie together have
an undeniable chemistry and a
wonderful feel, which makes Susie's
exit all the more frustrating. She's
strangely absent from the final act,
and we're left with Frank, stuck in
suburbia with the kids; and Jack,
moping about his failures as a blues
pianist. Meanwhile, Susie, the
catalyst, has gone to sing vegetable
commercials. As "The Fabulous
Baker Boys" ends, you may wonder
why Kloves chose to break up such
a successful trio.

AN INNOCENT MAN
Peter Yates' prison drama is as
predictable and intelligence-insulting
as a bad TV movie. Tom Selleck
plays Jimmie Rainwood, a triumphant airline mechanic sent to prison
for a crime he didn't commit. While
in the big house, he watches a friend
burn to death and observes the gangrape of a white prisoner by a group
of black inmates, just for starters.
How could Selleck be anything but
innocent? He's predictably spineless
in prison, but when he gets paroled

The process of applying for and winning grants
by Katherine Mansour
As members of a major
research university, Johns
Hopkins faculty are responsible
for obtaining funds from outside
sources and sponsors to conduct
research in various fields from

to Medicine. While the nature of
the research may vary greatly
from one field to the next, the
process of securing grants and
contracts for research is essentially the same.
According to Cheryl LeeHoward, Assistant Dean of the
Homewood Research Administration, researchers first
conceive of an idea and then try
to find an organization that will
support them in the examination
of their particular hypotheses.
"Basically," stated Dean

Milton T. Cole, Research Administrator for the School of Arts
and Sciences, admitted that
"many faculty prefer to seek out
sponsors on their own."
However his colleague, Joan F.
Warfield, handling the G.W.C.
Whiting School of Engineering,
added, "We are continually
receiving announcements and
disseminating information to
faculty on programs which might
be of interest to them."
The faculty and students either
plod through the extensive collection of program announcements
compiled in the Administration's
in-house library or do a computerized search on SPIN and
IRIS.

SPIN (Sponsored Programs Information System) and IRIS (Illinois Researcher Information
System) are available to anyone
at Hopkins, and the University administration covers all costs,
which amount to approximately
$6,000 per year.
Users enter in personal dataeducational background, areas of

minutes, the system comes up
with a number of programs compatible with the researchers' interests and qualifications. Approximately one week later, users
receive a computerized report
listing detailed information about
the sponsors and programs.

"since Homewood Schools are in

for their schools." "However,"
added Elrod, "they are just tools

and eventually to submit a proposal... and funding is never
guaranteed."

Ice hockey skates past Salisbury,
in 6-2 opening victory
by Jay Calkins
Baltimore, October 22.
The Johns Hopkins ice hockey
team started its season in impressive fashion as they rolled
past Salisbury State by a
score of 6-2.
As anticipated, the defense was
stifling as they limited the
Seagulls to just 20 shots. Junior
goaltender Dave Bowyer was
outstanding in the net as he made
18 saves, but he was quick to
credit his defense for much of his
success. "Our guys really put the
clamp on their offense. It was a
challenge for me to keep my concentration while facing so few
shots."
The offense, thought to be the
question mark for the team, provided the needed punch with a
balanced scoring attack in which
five different Blue Jays scored.
The first period began as a
stalemate as both teams held
the other in check for the first 6
minutes. The Jays drew first
blood, however, as freshman
Jason Sprague sent a beautiful
pass across the middle to senior
Jack Calkins, who was waiting on
the left post to drive it home. One
minute later, Sprague completed
a spin move to open up the ice
and again found Calkins on the
post where Jack was able to collect his second goal of the night.
The Jays maintained this torrid

first period pace when playmaker
Sprague assisted for the third time
by hitting Pierre DeMatos high in
the slot. DeMatos took one step
toward the goal before rifling a
shot past the left shoulder of
Salisbury's goalie to give
Hopkins a 3-0 advantage.
After letting up a goal at the tail
end of the first period, the
stickmen took the ice in the second period looking to leave their
opponents in the dust. Right from
the opening whistle the Jays were
all over them, and the hustle paid
off. Jon Lowthert took a pass
from senior captain Mike
Holmes deep in his own zone.
Lowthert skated the puck by two
defenders before making a blind
behind the back pass to Norm
Shephard, who was wide open in
front of the net. Shephard easily
beat the Salisbury goalie to extend
the Jays' lead to 4-1.
After a 7-minute lull in the action, Phil Schied made a superb
defensive play when he successfully thwarted the efforts of
two rushing Salisbury forwards.
Seeing the five-on-three advantage he had created, Schied found
Kirk Perry all alone beyond the
Salisbury defense. Perry approached the goal on a difficult
angle from the right side, but was
still able to slip the puck between
the legs of the opposing
goaltender.
A minute and a half later

Holmes found Dave Boxenbaum
at center ice, where Boxenbaum
was able to beat two deferders in
order to set up a snap shot from
15 feet out. Salisbury's goalie appeared to make the save, but
juggled the puck into his own net
to make the score 6-1.
Salisbury responded to this last
goal 50 seconds later, but were
unable to create any momentum
for themselves.
The third period provided no
scoring, due largely to fine
goaltending. Bowyer frustrated
the Salisbury offense by making
repeated saves. "He's unbeatable
on that glove side," commented
Holmes.
The season-opening victory
was very satisfying for the team,
but they realize that the Salisbury
squad was not representative of
the type of competition they will
face this season. "It was a great
win," offered Coach Steve
Wirth, "but we're going to have
to improve even more in order to
be competitive in league play.
Against teams like Georgetown
we have to stay intense for the
whole game and not just for two
periods like today."
Next up for the hockey team is
rival Western Maryland on Saturday at 7:15 p.m. at Northwest Ice
Rink, on Falls Road and Kelly
Street in Mount Washington
Village.

Cambridge, MA, Oct. 22—
Two varsity crew teams
represented the Johns Hopkins
University at the 25th annual
Head of the Charles Regatta. In
its first Head race of the season,
a young, strong men's
heavyweight boat placed 15th out
of 38 in the Club Four event. A
more experienced women's crew
returning from a successful spring
season pulled in a 7th place performance out of 23 in the Championship Four category.
A Head race is typically 21
2 to
/
3½ miles long, a demanding
distance. Boats are started one at
a time at ten-second intervals.
The challenge of a Head race lies
in racing against the clock while
trying to pass boats ahead and
hold off boats from behind.
Headracing, especially on the
Charles River, is the greatest test
of a coxswain's abilities, particularly in terms of steering the
most efficient path and keeping
the rowers motivated.
At 9:00 AM, the men's Club
Fours began powering down the
course. Bow number 29 shot into view propelled by the drive of
strokeman Dan Taylor, Chris
Ros, Greg Stella, and bowman
Erik Plautz. Cox E.K. Kim, in
firm control, steered past the Latvian National Masters boat from
the U.S.S.R. Despite a hairraising clashing of blades with the

College of St. Thomas, Minnesota, the Hopkins Four and
Kim remained cool and finished
in 19:29.
At 2:55 p.m., the starting time
of the Championship Four event
bore down, winds wound up, tensions monted and anxieties
climaxed.
Coxswain Veronica Rodriguez
assumed strategic position as she
motivated her rowers through the
start. Over the three-mile stretch,
the Hopkins Four outstripped two
competitors while nipping at the
stern of the Seattle crew.
Assisted ty the steady power of
stroke Kim Roberts, Inge Schlate,
and Kelly Kieffer, Rodriguez
coxed a strategically brilliant boat
race. The seventh place finish at
21:36 is impressive, considering
such competition as the firstplace national powerhouse Boston
Rowing Center (20:06), secondplace Vancouver Rowing Club
Canada and such highly regarded college crews as U.C.L.A.,
H a rand
Wisconsin,
vard/Radcliffe. The women's
performance is the strongest ever
of a Hopkins crew entered in the
Head of the Charles Regatta.
The success on the Charles
River of both the men's and
women's crews bodes good
tidings for the three remaining
races of the fall season. The varsity men's Lightweight Eight and
the men's and women's Novice
Eights are expected to join them
in future victories.

A fall for lacrosse

Soccer captures pair

Loyola shocks Jays in overtime
by Josh Orenstein
When Brian Kroneberger lifted
Loyola College to an 11-10 victory over the Blue Jays in the first
round of the Choice Visa
Lacrosse Classic, disappointment
and frustration were inevitable.
But last weekend's game has to
be kept in perspective. It was an
off-season exhibition without any
effect on rankings or records.
"The worst thing anyone could
do now is push the panic button,"
said head coach Don Zimmerman. "If anyone should push it,
it's me, and I'm certainly not."
For the first 58 minutes of
regulation, the Blue Jays
displayed a typical, successful
performance: the Jays started off
very strong, held a slim lead at
halftime, dominated the third
quarter, and were in control in the
fourth. With a 10-6 Hopkins lead
and less than two minutes remaining, all looked well. So Zimmerman relaxed and substituted
extensively.
Brian Kroneberger cut the

Hopkins margin to three goals
with one minute, 52 seconds to
play. Still, all was well. Then
came the two-pointer. For the
Classic, Choice Visa introduced
a two-point goal, awarded on any
goal scored on a shot taken between the midfield line and a
semicircular arc extending 17
yards from the center of the
crease. The two-point goal will
not be used in games this spring.
Hopkins had benefitted first
from the innovation, as Greg Kelly beat Loyola goalie Charlie
Toomey from 17 feet with 22
seconds remaining in the third
period to increase a 7-3 Jay lead
to 9-3. At that point, the twopoint idea seemed novel, but
rather insignificant.
Kroneberger's two-pointer
with 67 seconds remaining
changed that thinking. Suddenly
the Greyhounds trailed by only
one goal. Zimmerman returned to
his starting troops, but it Was too
late. Momentum was lost, and the
'Hounds were hungry.
Loyola's Paul Cantabene won

the ensuing faceoff, raced down
the field, and fired past allAmerican goaltender Quint
Kessenich to tie the game. One
minute, 47 seconds into overtime
Kroneberger ended it.
"I've got to give Loyola a lot
of credit," said Zimmerman.
"They hung tough. Not to take
anything away from them, but I
take full responsibility for the
loss. I learned something about
the two-pointer today. I was
coaching without thinking about
it, and I'm at fault for that.—
Loyola coach Dave Cottle was
reserved in his enthusiasm about
defeating last year's national
runner-up. "It was a good
game," said the coach, "but all
it means is that we played tough
in a fall game."
Sunday, in the tournament's
consolation game, the Jays released their frustration on MarylandBaltimore County, earning a 20-6
conquest. It was an enjoyable
rout, but only a fall game.

Johns Hopkins' varsity rifle
started the year plagued by ill fortune, but the team still managed
to make strong showings in its
first three matches this year.
During the summer, an ROTC
instructor, much to the chagrin of
the rifle team and the Athletic
Department, requested a government environmental test of the
Hopkins rifle range. The test
found the range in violation of
lead dust safety levels, and the
state of Maryland condemned and
sealed the rifle range and fined
the Athletic Department $5000.
The loss of the range severely
reduced the amount of practice
before the season's first three
matches, and the lack of practice
showed itself in the inconsistent
scores of the teams' top shooters.
However, the team as a whole did
remarkably well in the first match
at King's College in Pennsylvania. Hopkins earned 1975
points out of a possible 2400.
This score beat Cornell by 25
points.
Last weekend, the rifle team
shot an early morning match at
Navy. The Jays lost to the Division I rifle giant, but did well
against DePaul University. Then,
the team travelled to Lexington,
Virginia, to fire against Virginia
Military Institute and Army in a
Sunday morning shootout. The
two Division I schools beat Johns
Hopkins as expected, but the
Hopkins shooters produced consistently high scores, including a
perfect 100 prone target shot by
senior Jim Kielkopf.
The matches are shot using .22
caliber precision target rifles at a
range of fifty feet. The targets,
or "bulls" are coin-sized black
circles, and the ten-point "bull's
eye— is the size of a pin head. A
